entities.name: Information Conservation
entities.description: The principle that information is never lost, which is a fundamental concept in quantum mechanics.

entities.name: singularity
entities.description: A point of infinite density and zero volume at the center of a black hole.

entities.name: Black Hole Evaporation
entities.description: The process by which black holes lose mass and eventually evaporate due to Hawking radiation.

entities.name: Astronomers
entities.description: Astronomers are scientists who study celestial objects, space, and the physical universe as a whole. They have been instrumental in understanding black holes and other cosmic phenomena.

entities.name: MASSIVE STARS
entities.description: Stars with masses significantly greater than our Sun.

entities.name: HOLOGRAPHIC PRINCIPLE
entities.description: The holographic principle is a concept in theoretical physics suggesting that all the information about the contents of a black hole is encoded on its event horizon, challenging traditional views on information storage in the universe.

entities.name: gravitational time dilation
entities.description: causes time to slow near black holes

entities.name: evaporation
entities.description: The transition of liquid to vapor through heat loss.

entities.name: New Ideas in Quantum Mechanics
entities.description: Quantum mechanics is a fundamental theory in physics that describes the physical properties of nature at the scale of atoms and subatomic particles.

entities.name: classical general relativity
entities.description: A framework describing gravity as curvature of spacetime.

entities.name: SCHWARZSCHILD RADIUS
entities.description: The Schwarzschild radius is the radius at which the escape velocity equals the speed of light, defining the boundary of a black hole's event horizon.

entities.name: Traditional Understanding of Information Storage
entities.description: The traditional understanding of information storage assumes that information is stored within the volume of an object.

entities.name: fundamental laws of physics
entities.description: The fundamental laws of physics are the basic principles that govern the behavior of matter and energy in the universe. These laws form the foundation of modern physics and include theories such as general relativity, quantum mechanics, and the standard model.

entities.name: speed of light
entities.description: The maximum speed at which information can travel through space-time.

entities.name: mass loss
entities.description: The reduction of mass from an object over time.

entities.name: radiation
entities.description: A faint glow emitted by black holes due to quantum effects near the event horizon.

entities.name: New Ideas in String Theory
entities.description: String theory is a theoretical framework in which the point-like particles of particle physics are replaced by one-dimensional objects called strings.

entities.name: galaxies
entities.description: Galaxies are vast systems composed of billions to trillions of stars, along with gas, dust, and dark matter. They come in various shapes and sizes, such as spiral, elliptical, and irregular.

entities.name: quantum effects
entities.description: Quantum effects refer to the unpredictable and probabilistic behaviors of particles at the quantum level, which can influence macroscopic phenomena like black hole radiation.

entities.name: quantum gravity
entities.description: A theoretical framework that combines quantum mechanics and general relativity.
